Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Disintermediation and the Reorganization of Labor

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research exploring changes in the contemporary workplace have tended to focus on the shift from waged, contracted employment to more flexible labor arrangements. Some view these as preconditions for creative economies that can transform productive landscapes. Others are concerned with the extent to which these regimes have generated precarity in the labor force. But what conclusions can be made when the focus of study is on those who have historically functioned outside the discipline of contract labor practices, such as artisans, merchants, and middlemen? This project, which trains a graduate student in how to conduct rigorous, empirically grounded scientific fieldwork, addresses a broader phenomenon that economists refer to as "disintermediation," in which middlemen are being cut out of industries and supply-chains. Global in scope and interconnected in configuration, disintermediation is rapidly transforming the lives of workers everywhere: in the fast-fashion apparel and fair trade coffee supply-chains, the hospitality and tourism sectors, and the taxi service industry. In addition to providing funding for the training of a graduate student in anthropology, findings will be disseminated to organizations and individuals that explore and manage the causes, consequences, and complexities of economic precarity.

Samuel Shuman, under the supervision of Dr. Jatin Dua of the University of Michigan, will explores what role disintermediation has in the reorganization of labor. The research takes place among a Hasidic community in Antwerp, Belgium, who is now in the process of reskilling its male workforce and refashioning them into local entrepreneurs. After World War II, thousands of Jewish refugees fled Eastern Europe to Western Europe. Among these refugees were Hasidim, a pietistic sect of Judaism, which landed in the port-city of Antwerp. Over 80% of its workforce depended upon the diamond industry for their economic livelihoods. In recent years, however, through the rise of national and supranational forms of regulation and e-commerce, Hasidic Jews are being cut out as middlemen in the diamond supply-chain. Within the context of this transition, the study asks three series of questions: 1) How are attitudes toward work, value, and virtue becoming reshaped through this economic transformation and through austerity policies? 2) How is surveillance informing how transactions are both conducted within the regulated industry and within an emerging, local community of entrepreneurs? 3) What does this economic transition reveal about the role of the middleman within the long history of global Capitalism and what might it illuminate about a new phase of Capitalism where middlemen may no longer be needed? Data will be gathered through a range of established ethnographic techniques over a 12-month period, including participant observation and interviews among attendees at a vocational school, traders, brokers, and artisans in the diamond bourse. In contributing to scientific work in legal and economic anthropology, this project emphasizes the economic middleman as the exemplary figure through which to understand the reorganization of modern political economies and the boundaries of inclusion and exclusion within these worlds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project addresses a broader phenomenon that economists refer to as "disintermediation," in which middlemen are being cut out of industries and supply-chains. Global in scope and interconnected in configuration, disintermediation is rapidly transforming the lives of workers everywhere: in the fast-fashion apparel and fair trade coffee supply-chains, the hospitality and tourism sectors, and the taxi service industry. 

Samuel Shuman, an Anthropology PhD candidate at the University of Michigan, explored what role disintermediation has in the reorganization of labor. The research took place among a Hasidic community in Antwerp, Belgium, who is now in the process of reskilling its male workforce and refashioning them into local entrepreneurs.

 
The researcher discovered a stark generational divide within the Hasidic community concerning the value of work. On the one side lie the attitudes of the prior generation, who tied their sense of status, class, and identity to the luxury of the diamond and the easy money it afforded them. On the other side lie the attitudes of a new generation, who tie their sense of status, class, and identity to a type of masculinity associated with embodied "hard work" and skilled vocational training. Rather than pitting the value of religious learning against the value of working, as assumed by the dominant literature on Ultra-Orthodox Jewish communities, Hasidic men must negotiate shifting communal atittudes and taboos about what qualifies as proper work befitting a Hasidic man. This is often compounded by: 1) a perceived lack of intra-communal Jewish solidarity for their businesses; 2) economic antisemitism of their Flemish "autochtonous" neighbors who bar them entry from working for large companies and firms (rather than as petty capitalists or as workers for Jewish-operated small businesses); 3) mistreatment by their bosses; 4) lack of economic support & intervention by communal rabbinic authorities; and 5) lack of proper educational training for the workforce. 

Through the course of research, significant differences between the disintermediation of rough and polished brokers were discovered, revealing both broader divisions within the organizational structure of the industry and the limitations that the very materiality of the diamond itself places upon its circulation. Whereas polished diamonds, for example, can be easily traded via e-commerce platforms that link the seller directly to the consumer, rough diamonds cannot be easily sold to the consumer via e-commerce platforms.
Despite these differences, the vast majority of diamond industry actors interviewed argued that the total disintermediation of the broker will never be actualized. The broker's value is one marked by affective labor and service that e-commerce platforms cannot provide. Perceived as a neutral third party, the broker must negotiate between the egos of both supplier and boss. Indeed, with the mistrust that now pervades the industry, the broker's value now assumes new significance. As mobile actors, they can gather data about a client's reputation by interacting with traders across the diamond industry, capitalizing upon an unquantifiable human sense or skill for perceiving trustworthiness, which e-commerce platforms cannot access. 
These findings suggest that new technologies of disintermediation do not simply eliminate the role of traditional middlemen in global capitalism. These technologies, rather, in a more itterative sense, force humans to clarify and capitalize upon what is uniquely "human" in the services they provide.
